Lancing The Sacred Cow
Erv Sekulow's open statement to the Hopkins community in reference to the 'Gentleman's Code' reminds us
that idealism did not die with Leibnitz. Gentlemanliness
is a proper topic for abstractionists and metaphysicians,
but for the Student Council, ideally a group of realistic
reformers, never, never.
The constructive work of the Gentleman's Code Committee strikes us as being as nebulous as the 'Gentleman's
Code' itself, or about as hazy as a British bog on a rainy
day. `Gentlemanliness' no longer is judged by title or
heritage, but is a state of being based upon individual upbringing and experience. For the Student Council to
suggest that a student not steeped in the deep significance
of `gentlemanliness' query a Student Council member and
thus be enlightened is but an Umbrella-step short of
absurdity.
If the Student Council does feel that every action of
every undergraduate is not the most couth, and it certainly
is not, may we remind, remember that each undergraduate is man enough to agree to abide by an honor system,
that the dormitory students have self-government. We do
not dare suggest that the Student Council empower a committee to levy punishment against offenders of the 'Gentleman's Code' for we realize that the 'Code' is a physical
non-entity. But we do ask, that unless the SC can arrive
upon some concrete reforms with reference to actions at
campus functions, that it bear in mind that this is not
the best of all possible worlds, and that boys will be boys.

First of all, to call football an American game is somewhat misleading. True, the game is now played almost
exclusively in America, but it comes to us from a land
far away and a civilization long dead.
Football was first played in ancient Rome. Introduced
by Julius Caesar, it became one of the most popular
Roman sports_by the time of Nero's reign. The eminpnt
historian, Sigafoos, reVorts a crowd of MMCLDDXVIII
people at the Colosseum one Saturday afternoon to see
the Christians play the Lions.
With the decline of the Roman empire, football fell
into disuse. The barbaric-Huns and Visigoths preferred
canasta. Not until the fifteenth century A. D. did football emerge from its twilight and rise to its rightful place
in the firmament of European sports.
Which brings us to September 29, 1442, a date dear to
the hearts of all football fans. It was on this date, according to the eminent historian Sigafoos, that a sixteen-yearold lad named Christopher Columbus tried out for the
football team at Genoa Tech. He failed to make the team
because he was too light.(He weighed at the time 'only
twelve pounds.)
And why, you ask, is this date—September 29, 1442—
so dear to the hearts of all football fans? Because young
Columbus was so heartbroken at not making the team
that he ran away to sea. And if that hadn't happened,
he never would have discovered America. And if Columbus
hadn't discovered America the world would never have
discovered tobacco. And if? the world hadn't discovered
tobacco, football fans never would have discovered
Marlboro—which,as every fan knows,is the perfect companion to football. And why shouldn't it be? Look what
Marlboro's got... Filter... Flavor... Flip-top Box ...
You can't buy a better smoke. You can't smoke a better
buy.
The end of football in Europe came with the notorious
"Black Sox Scandal" of 1587, in which Ed Machiavelli,
one of the Pisa mob,paid off the University of Heidelberg
Sabres to throw the championship game to the Chartres
A. and M. Gophers. It was a mortal blow to football on
the continent.
But the game took bold in the American colonies and
thrived as it had never thrived before. Which brings us
to another date that remains evergreen in the hearts of
football lovers: December 16, 1773.
On tat date a British packet loaded with tea sailed
into Boston harbor. The colonies had long been smarting
under the English king's tax on tea. "Taxation without
representation," they called it, and feelings ran high.
When on December 16, 1f73, the British ship docked
at Boston, a semi-pro football team'called the Nonpareil
Tigers, coached by Samuel (Sway) Adams, was scrimmaging near the harbor. "Come,lads," cried Sway,seeing the ship. "Let's dump the tea in the ocean!"
With many a laugh and cheer the Nonpareil Tigers
followed Sway aboard and proceeded to dump the
cargo overboard in a wild, disorganized -and abandoned
manner. "Here now!" called Sway sharply. "That's no
way .to dump tea overboard. Let's get into some kind
of formation."
And that, fans, is how the tea formation was born.

Erv Sekulow's open statement to the Hopkins community in reference to the 'Gentleman's Code' reminds us
that idealism did not die with Leibnitz. Gentlemanliness
is a proper topic for abstractionists and metaphysicians,
but for the Student Council, ideally a group of realistic
reformers, never, never.
The constructive work of the Gentleman's Code Committee strikes us as being as nebulous as the 'Gentleman's
Code' itself, or about as hazy as a British bog on a rainy
day. `Gentlemanliness' no longer is judged by title or
heritage, but is a state of being based upon individual upbringing and experience. For the Student Council to
suggest that a student not steeped in the deep significance
of `gentlemanliness' query a Student Council member and
thus be enlightened is but an Umbrella-step short of
absurdity.

every undergraduate is not the most couth, and it certainly
is not, may we remind, remember that each undergraduate is man enough to agree to abide by an honor system,
that the dormitory students have self-government. We do
not dare suggest that the Student Council empower a committee to levy punishment against offenders of the 'Gentleman's Code' for we realize that the 'Code' is a physical
non-entity. But we do ask, that unless the SC can arrive
upon some concrete reforms with reference to actions at
campus functions, that it bear in mind that this is not
the best of all possible worlds, and that boys will be boys.

First of all, to call football an American game is somewhat misleading. True, the game is now played almost
exclusively in America, but it comes to us from a land
far away and a civilization long dead.
Football was first played in ancient Rome. Introduced
by Julius Caesar, it became one of the most popular
Roman sports_by the time of Nero's reign. The eminpnt
historian, Sigafoos, reVorts a crowd of MMCLDDXVIII
people at the Colosseum one Saturday afternoon to see
the Christians play the Lions.
With the decline of the Roman empire, football fell
into disuse. The barbaric-Huns and Visigoths preferred
canasta. Not until the fifteenth century A. D. did football emerge from its twilight and rise to its rightful place
in the firmament of European sports.
Which brings us to September 29, 1442, a date dear to
the hearts of all football fans. It was on this date, according to the eminent historian Sigafoos, that a sixteen-yearold lad named Christopher Columbus tried out for the
football team at Genoa Tech. He failed to make the team
because he was too light.(He weighed at the time 'only
twelve pounds.)
And why, you ask, is this date—September 29, 1442—
so dear to the hearts of all football fans? Because young
Columbus was so heartbroken at not making the team
that he ran away to sea. And if that hadn't happened,
he never would have discovered America. And if Columbus
hadn't discovered America the world would never have
discovered tobacco. And if? the world hadn't discovered
tobacco, football fans never would have discovered
Marlboro—which,as every fan knows,is the perfect companion to football. And why shouldn't it be? Look what
Marlboro's got... Filter... Flavor... Flip-top Box ...
You can't buy a better smoke. You can't smoke a better
buy.
The end of football in Europe came with the notorious
"Black Sox Scandal" of 1587, in which Ed Machiavelli,
one of the Pisa mob,paid off the University of Heidelberg
Sabres to throw the championship game to the Chartres
A. and M. Gophers. It was a mortal blow to football on
the continent.
But the game took bold in the American colonies and
thrived as it had never thrived before. Which brings us
to another date that remains evergreen in the hearts of
football lovers: December 16, 1773.
On tat date a British packet loaded with tea sailed
into Boston harbor. The colonies had long been smarting
under the English king's tax on tea. "Taxation without
representation," they called it, and feelings ran high.
When on December 16, 1f73, the British ship docked
at Boston, a semi-pro football team'called the Nonpareil
Tigers, coached by Samuel (Sway) Adams, was scrimmaging near the harbor. "Come,lads," cried Sway,seeing the ship. "Let's dump the tea in the ocean!"
With many a laugh and cheer the Nonpareil Tigers
followed Sway aboard and proceeded to dump the
cargo overboard in a wild, disorganized -and abandoned
manner. "Here now!" called Sway sharply. "That's no
way .to dump tea overboard. Let's get into some kind
of formation."
And that, fans, is how the tea formation was born.

"The department is not ready to make an official

Wrestling was dropped from the Hopkins intercollegiate athletic program in December, 1956, due to a lack of

freshmen mat candidates were working out when the announcement was made.

tennis balls I guess."

the Mason-Dixon tourney title in 1942, 1946, 1947, 1948,
1949, 1950, plus the tie in 1954 with Gallaudet.
Wrestling was dropped from the Hopkins program
also in 1953, because of a lack of student participation.
However, an informal team worked out under Coach
Mickey Cochrane, and tied Gallaudet for the M-D Conference Tournament championship.
